segments.text: The campaign was on the heels of Sharpstown and at a time when the Speaker of the House was being tried for bribery in Abilene.
I was going on during the political campaign.
Legislators were running for cover.
When I received a call,
asking me if I would come to Abilene and testify.
Even though I had a campaign and had opponents that would obviously make use of such a trip, I decided that I could not in good conscience say no.
I made the trip to Abilene, arrived there one evening to find out that
the defense had rested and decided to not call any witnesses.
I never have understood why the defense rested in that case without calling witnesses, but that was the decision they made.
Shortly after returning home, the jury found Speaker Butcher guilty of bribery
and were prepared to sentence him.
I then received a second call to please come back to Abilene and appear as a character witness.
I did make a trip to Abilene and was prepared to appear as a character witness but was never called.
The fact that I had made the trips to Abilene and even though there was no record
of my appearing in Abilene, the election campaign got very nasty and every effort was made to link me with the Speaker.
I think the biggest mistake I made was not getting the family together and explaining to them what was going on and why I was conducting myself as I was.
that even the older children did not understand all the mudslinging and name-calling that was taking place.
Recall one evening, we're sitting down to dinner, my five-year-old daughter came in and said, Daddy, that man is back on TV again saying, where was Bill Presnell when he was supposed to be
her hands on her hips and was very indignant about it all.
Changed her expression finally to say, where were you, Daddy?
That particular attack had nothing to do with Sharpstown, but had everything to do with the fact that a special session was called during the political campaign.
And at a time when I had a commitment
to be at a barbecue that was given in my honor, Robertson County, a county which had been newly added to the district.
The fact was that I had stayed in Austin until late that afternoon and made arrangements for a friend to pick me up in his airplane.
But I could get the details of some legislation worked out before leaving the Capitol.
Same opponent was running an ad in the newspaper each day for about 30 days that simply said, why did Preston go to Abilene?
In the meantime, the Dirty Thirty was supporting another candidate that I had as an opponent.
And I recall one evening at a political rally when he pointed out that the Dirty Thirty was supporting him and his candidacy to defeat me for reelection.
I followed up to point out that the leader of the Dirty Thirty
was the person who had passed a resolution to commend the Boston Strangler.
A campaign year when it was throw the rascals out and I feel very fortunate that I survived the campaign with two opponents without having to face a runoff.
have a special session later that year after the campaigns were over, and at that session on the first day, Speaker Murcher resigned from his post as Speaker of the House.
This meant that we had to elect a new Speaker, and the test was between Rayford Price and DeWitt Hale.

I chose to support Rayford Price because we all knew that DeWitt Hale was merely a stand-in for the interim so that Price Daniel Jr. could be elected speaker come 19 January 1973 for the regular session.
Price Daniel Jr. did not want to
run the risk of being defeated in this election that was held during the special session.

The Constitution requires that a speaker be elected at the convening of each regular session of the legislature unless there's a vacancy and then of course there has to be an election to fill the vacancy.
In a close election, Rayford Price was elected Speaker, but was later defeated in his campaign for re-election by Fred Head, who he had been paired with in the redistricting process.
The defeat of Rayford Price threw the doors wide open for Price Daniel Jr. to be elected speaker when the legislature convened in January 1973.
It was during this special session in 1972 that I agreed to disperse of my dairy herd and have a state representative
auctioneer the cattle off.
Sale was held in December and I felt that this was positioning me to either to leave the legislature and find a full-time employment upon the completion of the regular session in 1973.
There was always a possibility that I could find employment that would allow me to continue to serve in the legislature, but there were no guarantees.
The legislative session convening in January 1973 became known as the Reform Session.
We had a new speaker in Price Daniel, Jr. We had a new lieutenant governor in Bill Hobby and a new governor in Dolph Briscoe.
The first actions that a new legislature takes is to adopt its rules of procedure.
This usually follows immediately after the election of the Speaker.
The legislature had adopted some changes in the rules during the special session under Rayford Price.
One of those rules required
that a person that served on a committee continue to serve on that committee as long as he was in the legislature.
We called it the retention seniority rule.
The rules were laid out.
I found that the retention seniority rule had been removed.
And so when the time came to take the vote on the rules,
I voted against the rules.
When you vote against the rules, you're voting against the speaker.
And this vote probably cost me a seat on the House Appropriations Committee.
I just could not bring myself to vote for rules that remove the retention seniority rule, which I thought was a good rule and would provide continuity
on the committee.
I think that is sorely needed on all committees in the House of Representatives.
Instead of serving on the House Appropriations Committee, which has consumed so much time, I was placed on the Education Committee.
I was chaired by Dan Kubiak.

Being served on the Appropriations Committee for two terms gave me a different perspective with regards to education legislation that came before the committee, and I felt like I was able to make a contribution to the piece of legislation that we were able to prevail upon.
had to do with the way public kindergarten was structured.
In 1971, a kindergarten bill had been passed, but it was not to allow all five-year-olds to attend public kindergarten.
It was very difficult, almost impossible to explain to the public why the
legislature passed such a bill saying that half of the children could go to public kindergarten but half of them could not.
Came up with the idea that we could do the same thing for the same money by making kindergarten half day and allowing all children to attend.
I had just finished going to a private kindergarten and it was my impression that
attending for a half a day, which she did, was adequate and all that a five-year-old could handle.
I did not have the votes in committee to prevail on the issue, but adopted a strategy that I have never seen used before or since with regards to influencing legislation.

I conspired with two or three members to attend the committee meetings but with the understanding that they would not attend the meetings and therefore the committee would not have a quorum and could not take a vote.
I needed to be there to be sure to challenge the chairman that a quorum was not present and that he could not take a vote.
After several weeks I was
contacted by the lobbyists for the Texas State Teachers Association and agreed that to a half-day kindergarten program if I would help get a quorum back to the Education Committee meeting.
Agreed, and at the next meeting we had a quorum and voted the bill out with a half-day kindergarten provision.
It was also in 1973 that the new members, which there were many, decided that there should be a Constitutional Convention.
So by resolution, one was created to convene in 1974.
The members of the Constitutional Convention would be the members of the Texas House and the Texas Senate.
Early in the session, the reform bills started pouring out of committees, such bills as open meetings, open records, etc.
There was a lobby control bill, and all these bills had serious constitutional questions and concerns.
the members of the House were determined to pass the legislation because of the political consequences if they voted against them.
I voted against most of these bills because I felt like they were bad legislation.
I recorded my reason for voting against certain bills, particularly the lobby control bill, and
This was very helpful when the campaign season rolled around and my opponent was attempting to use this as a campaign issue.
We'll discuss this in more detail later.
A bill that I was happy to co-sponsor would create a veterinary diagnostic laboratory in Amarillo and would be
a part of the laboratory in College Station that is under the direction of the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents.
The primary sponsors of the bill both in the House and the Senate were from Amarillo where the lab would be located.
We were able to pass the bill in the House and send it over to the Senate
When it left the House, it was unclear as to where the laboratory would be located.
When the House bill was returned by the Senate to the House, the amendment saying that the laboratory would be located in Amarillo had been added.
was unhappy with this language and I have never known what his problem was since he was a resident of Amarillo.
Rumor was that he wanted to locate it in Canyon on the campus of West Texas State University.
He never told me that.
The speaker was ready to concur in the Senate amendments to the House bill and send the bill on to the governor.
The speaker called me forward and told me that the sponsor was in the hospital and was there any controversy about the bill.
And I said, not if we pass it now.
He said, then let's move to concur.
I did move to concur knowing that the sponsor of the bill was not going to be happy with what I did.
Before that day, the sponsor was released from the hospital and came to the House floor and
made the unusual move to recall the bill.
Okay, two-thirds vote.
After he explained that he did not want the bill to pass in its present state, he was able to get a two-thirds vote.
He usually has a right to control his own bill to that extent.

Rather than send the bill to a conference committee, however, he placed the bill on the table, subject to call, which meant that it could be brought from the table and voted on, concurrence could be voted on at any time.
Texas Farm Bureau was keenly interested in seeing the bill passed, and on the last day, with the bill still laying on the table and not having been acted upon,
asked me if there was anything that could be done to pass the bill.
It suddenly occurred to me that there was a legislator in the Texas Panhandle that might could pass the bill if he would be willing to do so, but that I did not feel like that I could do it.
This legislator walked by about this time
And we called him aside and the Farm Bureau asked him if he would be willing to pick up the bill and pass it.
He said, if I get enough contact from constituents in my district that they want this bill passed before the day is out, I will pass it.
I will attempt to pass it.
The wife was from the Texas Panhandle and I knew
at least one cattleman in the Texas Panhandle that was very active politically.
So I placed a phone call to this person and explained the situation, and that was all that was necessary.
I'm sure the Farm Bureau was making its contacts at the same time, so in a short time,
there were on the desk of the panhandle legislator a large stack of telephone messages.
This provided the legislator the excuse that he needed to pick up and pass the bill, even though his colleague was still not for passing it.
As a result of that action, the Texas A&M University System Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory in Amarillo exists today.
One Sunday afternoon a supposedly non-controversial bill was placed on the consent calendar that provided
or the University of Texas system to have authority over marine-related research.
The University of Texas system had a fine facility at Port Aransas, but little use was being made of it.
It appeared that this bill would subtly give the University of Texas system statutory authority over all research dealing with the coast and the oceans.
Before Texas A&M University was training about half of the oceanographers in the world,
all at the graduate level.
I moved to block the bill from passage.
And I understand later that this created dialogue between the University of Texas system and the A&M system regarding oceanographic research and marine-related research for the first time.
To this day, Texas A&M is much stronger in the deep water, blue water, ocean research.
And University of Texas is predominantly in the business of providing research in the bays and estuaries.
To measure that, I was unable to stop in the House, but we were able to get it killed in the Senate.
dealt with the treatment of Prairie View by the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents.
There was a school of thought that Prairie View was being treated badly because of facilities that at Prairie View were not up to standards of those on the main campus.
Most of these facilities are supported
from non-tax revenues.
For example, the football coach, I'm told, wanted a new stadium there and could not understand why they could not build a new stadium using state funds.
When the resolution came up on the floor, Prairie View students had just testified before the House Appropriations Committee that from time to time they had no hot water
in the dormitories.
The issue became a racial one and members of the legislature who had minorities in their district still voted for the resolution.
They did not want to be labeled as a racist and wanted to get along with the minority members in the legislature as their numbers had grown
dramatically in the last redistricting.
One of the bills that I was carrying that session would have authorized new construction at the Uvalde Research Center under the Texas A&M University system.
It was the home of the governor and was a bill that he wanted to see passed.
The Senate had passed the bill very early in the session, but it was brought up in the Calendars Committee, not placed on the calendar until the last day of the session.
The bill was seven pages deep into the calendar,
And there was no way that the House was going to pass seven pages of bills on the last day of the session.
Early in the day, I spoke to the governor in his office about the problem.
He immediately turned and picked up a red telephone on his desk.
Ed Price, referring to the Speaker of the House, I want to see you in my office right now.
The Speaker left the podium and was in the Governor's office in less than two minutes.
I asked the Governor, should I leave?
And he said, no, you stay right there.
When the Speaker came in, the Governor informed him that
The bill that he wanted to see passed was on page seven, and he wanted the bill passed before the legislature adjourned that day.

Speaker proceeded to tell him that he had had problems with the state senator who was the author of the bill, and the governor interrupted and said, I'm concerned with your problems with the Senate sponsor.
This is a bill that I want to see passed.
The House of Representatives still had not gone on the calendar and started passing any of the bills.
Shortly thereafter, the first bill was laid out.
That first bill happened to be on the top of page seven.
To my amazement,
No one called a point of order that the speaker cannot start anywhere except at the top of the calendar, page one.
Finally, get to the bottom of the calendar where the Uvalde Research Center bill had been placed, and shortly after it was passed, the House adjourned.
sign he died.
House Daniel Jr., as Speaker, had agreed to serve only one term, and this, in my opinion, left him in somewhat a weakened position toward the end of the session.
The legislators were faced with a constitutional convention to convene in January of 1974
Price Daniel Jr. was the only person that was campaigning for to be chairman of the Constitutional Convention.
So in 1974, he was elected to chair the Constitutional Convention.
Also election year, and I drew another opponent.
that this time a city councilman from Bryan and a longtime personal friend.
Not take me long to realize that the local publisher of the local daily newspaper was helping my opponent in every way that he could.
Our campaign was getting a lot of publicity.
Most of it was
not to my favor.
I recall one Saturday morning picking up the paper and there was an article by my opponent reflecting upon my vote against the lobby control bill and how this was such a bad vote.
I immediately drafted a rebuttal and located the editor of the newspaper and told him that I would be bringing a rebuttal down and I expected to have equal space with my opponent.
The comment was that that article was supposed to run in the Sunday's paper.
And I said that someone made a mistake and ran it this morning on Saturday.
But I expected mine to be in the Sunday paper.
After a series of attacks by my opponent, I finally told the publisher of the paper one day that if the
race continue to be on the front page there would be no need for me to buy any paid advertising.
After that the story stopped.
This time the Constitutional Convention was going on which meant that for four days out of the week I was in Austin as a member of the Constitutional Convention.
I maintained some continuity
In the political campaign, I set up a Friday morning breakfast with constituents and campaign workers.
And this gave me a way to catch up on things that had happened during the week that I needed to be aware of.
And that the breakfast worked great in providing me with the information that I needed and
recruiting more campaign workers as we brought in new people from time to time to the breakfast.
The convention did take a 30-day recess prior to the primary election to allow the members to go home and campaign before the primary elections.
In Texas at that time there were few general elections and many primary elections.
or as state legislative races were concerned.
One of the issues my opponent raised through street talk was, was I a Christian?
Did I go to church?
Truth was that I had been teaching Sunday school in a small rural church for about nine or ten years.
held virtually every office in the local church where I was a member.
Question in my mind is how do you answer a rumor of that sort?
To me that an issue that would be coming before the Constitutional Convention in the very near future was one of gambling.
It sounds simple enough to simply say you're opposed to gambling,
But I had a very large constituency that liked to play bingo.
And there was a big question as to whether or not bingo would be included when the gambling issue came up.
I decided the best way to approach the issue before I made a statement that would hopefully
stop any further street talk about my Christian faith was to call a friend in the legislature who was a devout Catholic and get his views on how to handle the issue.
With his guidance, we were able to make a public release as to our opposition to gambling without alienating
a large constituency of people that like to play bingo.
And we hopefully defused the church issue for the balance of that campaign.
My opponent had worked many hours in Robertson County, and because of the Constitutional Convention, I was able to make very few trips to the county.
As a result, I did not feel good about the vote I would get in Hearn.
There was a scandal in Hearn at the time with regards to the city councilman.
And in addition to that, I had missed a big highway dedication in the town.
I did very well in Hearn.
I got 60% of the vote.
I knew that that was a signal that I would win the election.

I've often wondered if the fact that the local newspaper in Brine that had been carrying the Hearn scandal on the front page for so long had alienated the people in Hearn and when the paper endorsed my opponent, it may have backfired and helped me in
in the surrounding area.
It did hurt my ego not to get the endorsement of the local newspaper.
It may have done as much good as it did harm.
The election was over and I had won.
I returned to Austin to finish up the work on the Constitutional Convention.
The education committee was the first one to finish its work and I had been given primary responsibility for rewriting the permanent university fund section of the education article.
Able to keep the higher education portion intact and the permanent university fund intact with very little controversy.
Most of the controversy dealt with the constitutional provision that provides for the school system.
The big issue was the use of the term equal educational opportunity and what this meant.
It was viewed by some conservatives as a threat to local control.
that the education article was the first article that the speaker wanted out on the floor to be debated and passed in the Constitutional Convention by the full convention.
And ironically, he relied on me to help him get the bill out very quickly.
a little ribbing over this by some of my colleagues who were observing what was going on, saying they were glad that Daniel and I were finally getting along, something that we could agree on.
The education article in the Constitutional Convention went rather smoothly compared to some of the other articles.
The article that

got the most debate was the general provisions article the reasons that every issue that one could think of could fit under the general provisions article that one of the legislators who was known for his levity and used it as a way to make a point now and then offered an amendment to license environmentalists
as an amendment to the General Provisions article of the Constitution.
To paraphrase him, that he had sat on a committee the session before where some environmental bills had come up, and he said, we have people come before the committee and say they are concerned
environmentalists, and we do not know whether they're environmentalists or just some nut that walked in off the street.
For that reason, he was recommending that we license environmentalists and then we'd know which ones are environmentalists and which ones are just nuts that walk in off the street.
It was not serious, but he did make a point.
The race for Speaker was rather heated during the
Constitutional Convention and was an undertow that was play a rather significant role.
I refer to it as an undertow because you didn't see it every day, but you knew it was there.
For Speaker of the House to be elected in January 1975 was wide open.
There were
seven or eight legislators that were competing for the speakership.
I had decided early in the race to support Bill Clayton as a candidate for Speaker.
Clayton had become tagged as so conservative that he probably had little chance of ever winning the race.
The more likely winners were either Fred Head, who had the backing of all the new members of the legislature who he had campaigned with early on, and he had the backing of Labor.
Carl Parker, a third candidate, had a more moderate backing.
In fact, his support probably ranged from ultra-liberal to conservative.
He saw Parker as the eventual winner and probably for that reason supported him.
Price Daniel Jr., who was chairing the Constitutional Convention, had been a friend of Labor in the past, but decided that
He must include a right to work provision in the Constitution or it would fail.
The new members of the legislature that were serving their first term were the chief supporters of constitutional revision and wanted to see the Constitutional Convention succeed.
Fred Head saw an opportunity to rule the labor support for his speaker's race by going to labor and saying that he would not support the Constitutional Convention
document if they would support him for speaker.
So an agreement was struck.
I was a close lieutenant of Price Daniels, Jr., so this meant that he would vote for the constitutional revision.
Mixed emotions about how to vote for a constitutional revision.
had some real problems with some of the provisions that were there and felt like it was better not to have constitutional revision.
On the other hand, it would probably be in Mr. Clayton's favor if I voted for the constitutional revision.
Show good faith with the freshman members that wanted to see revision take place.
When the final vote was called for, it required 121 votes to be cast in favor of constitutional revision.
I voted for revision, but could see that it was going to fail.
The voting board was left open for an extended period of time in an attempt to get the 121 votes.
It started out with about 115 votes and eventually got to 118 but could never get above that number.
So it fell three votes short of passing the revision document
to the voting public for their approval or disapproval.
More importantly, it meant the demise of Mr. Head's race for the speakership.
It was after the Constitutional Convention had adjourned, the new members that were supporting Mr. Head announced that they were withdrawing their support from him
but were not committing to another candidate at that time.
They said they were going to take their time, interview all the candidates, and make their decision as a group.
A short time later, just before Labor Day in 1974, Fred Head,
to Bill Clayton and told him that his support had deteriorated and that he was ready to join forces with him, with Clayton, and see if he could help get him elected as Speaker.
Parker had felt all along that Fred Head's support would naturally come to him because there were many

of the more liberal members that were supporting fred head and they could not support mr clayton mr clayton however was able to persuade the more liberal faction that was supporting head that he would always be fair with them where they certainly would have questions in their own mind about parker treating them fairly all led to

a phone call I received on Friday before Labor Day saying that several of Mr. Clayton's supporters were getting together in Austin at the Driscoll Hotel to see if they could come use of support that Fred had given Mr. Clayton.
It was not a carefully planned out event,
I decided to go and call Saturday morning to say that I would be on my way shortly.
They asked me if I would pick up the new member that had been elected in the district just south of me.
He was one of the members that was uncommitted and was a holdout since they had broken with Fred Head.
I contacted the member, picked him up in Navasota, and we drove to Austin.
It turned out that he was very key in persuading the leadership of the new members to all come over to Mr. Clayton's side.
This was truly a Labor Day blitz that hit the opposition before they could recover.
